title: Alignment in std::ptr - Rust
markdown:
# Alignment in std::ptr - Rust

```
pub struct Alignment(/* private fields */);
```

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`ptr_alignment_type`Â [#102070](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/102070))

Expand description

A type storing a `usize` which is a power of two, and thus represents a possible alignment in the Rust abstract machine.

Note that particularly large alignments, while representable in this type, are likely not to be supported by actual allocators and linkers.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ptr/alignment.rs.html#24)[Â§](#impl-Alignment)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ptr/alignment.rs.html#38)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`ptr_alignment_type`Â [#102070](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/102070))

The smallest possible alignment, 1.

All addresses are always aligned at least this much.

##### [Â§](#examples)Examples

```
#![feature(ptr_alignment_type)]
use std::ptr::Alignment;

assert_eq!(Alignment::MIN.as_usize(), 1);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0A%23!%5Bfeature(ptr_alignment_type)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::ptr::Alignment;%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(Alignment::MIN.as_usize(),+1);%0A%7D&version=nightly&edition=2021)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ptr/alignment.rs.html#47)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`ptr_alignment_type`Â [#102070](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/102070))

Returns the alignment for a type.

This provides the same numerical value as [`mem::align_of`](../mem/fn.align_of.html "fn std::mem::align_of"), but in an `Alignment` instead of a `usize`.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ptr/alignment.rs.html#59)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`ptr_alignment_type`Â [#102070](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/102070))

Creates an `Alignment` from a `usize`, or returns `None` if itâ€™s not a power of two.

Note that `0` is not a power of two, nor a valid alignment.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ptr/alignment.rs.html#79)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`ptr_alignment_type`Â [#102070](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/102070))

Creates an `Alignment` from a power-of-two `usize`.

##### [Â§](#safety)Safety

`align` must be a power of two.

Equivalently, it must be `1 << exp` for some `exp` in `0..usize::BITS`. It must _not_ be zero.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ptr/alignment.rs.html#96)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`ptr_alignment_type`Â [#102070](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/102070))

Returns the alignment as a [`usize`](../primitive.usize.html "primitive usize").

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ptr/alignment.rs.html#104)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`ptr_alignment_type`Â [#102070](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/102070))

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ptr/alignment.rs.html#125)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`ptr_alignment_type`Â [#102070](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/102070))

Returns the base-2 logarithm of the alignment.

This is always exact, as `self` represents a power of two.

##### [Â§](#examples-1)Examples

```
#![feature(ptr_alignment_type)]
use std::ptr::Alignment;

assert_eq!(Alignment::of::<u8>().log2(), 0);
assert_eq!(Alignment::new(1024).unwrap().log2(), 10);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0A%23!%5Bfeature(ptr_alignment_type)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::ptr::Alignment;%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(Alignment::of::%3Cu8%3E().log2(),+0);%0A++++assert_eq!(Alignment::new(1024).unwrap().log2(),+10);%0A%7D&version=nightly&edition=2021)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ptr/alignment.rs.html#155)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`ptr_alignment_type`Â [#102070](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/102070))

Returns a bit mask that can be used to match this alignment.

This is equivalent to `!(self.as_usize() - 1)`.

##### [Â§](#examples-2)Examples

```
#![feature(ptr_alignment_type)]
#![feature(ptr_mask)]
use std::ptr::{Alignment, NonNull};

#[repr(align(1))] struct Align1(u8);
#[repr(align(2))] struct Align2(u16);
#[repr(align(4))] struct Align4(u32);
let one = <NonNull<Align1>>::dangling().as_ptr();
let two = <NonNull<Align2>>::dangling().as_ptr();
let four = <NonNull<Align4>>::dangling().as_ptr();

assert_eq!(four.mask(Alignment::of::<Align1>().mask()), four);
assert_eq!(four.mask(Alignment::of::<Align2>().mask()), four);
assert_eq!(four.mask(Alignment::of::<Align4>().mask()), four);
assert_ne!(one.mask(Alignment::of::<Align4>().mask()), one);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0A%23!%5Bfeature(ptr_alignment_type)%5D%0A%23!%5Bfeature(ptr_mask)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::ptr::%7BAlignment,+NonNull%7D;%0A++++%0A++++%23%5Brepr(align(1))%5D+struct+Align1(u8);%0A++++%23%5Brepr(align(2))%5D+struct+Align2(u16);%0A++++%23%5Brepr(align(4))%5D+struct+Align4(u32);%0A++++let+one+=+%3CNonNull%3CAlign1%3E%3E::dangling().as_ptr();%0A++++let+two+=+%3CNonNull%3CAlign2%3E%3E::dangling().as_ptr();%0A++++let+four+=+%3CNonNull%3CAlign4%3E%3E::dangling().as_ptr();%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(four.mask(Alignment::of::%3CAlign1%3E().mask()),+four);%0A++++assert_eq!(four.mask(Alignment::of::%3CAlign2%3E().mask()),+four);%0A++++assert_eq!(four.mask(Alignment::of::%3CAlign4%3E().mask()),+four);%0A++++assert_ne!(one.mask(Alignment::of::%3CAlign4%3E().mask()),+one);%0A%7D&version=nightly&edition=2021)

Expand description

A type storing a usize which is a power of two, and thus represents a possible alignment in the Rust abstract machine.

Note that particularly large alignments, while representable in this type, are likely not to be supported by actual allocators and linkers.

Returns a bit mask that can be used to match this alignment.

This is equivalent to !(self.as_usize() - 1).

Â§Examples
#![feature(ptr_alignment_type)]

use std::ptr::{Alignment, NonNull};

#[repr(align(1))] struct Align1(u8);
#[repr(align(2))] struct Align2(u16);
#[repr(align(4))] struct Align4(u32);

let two = <NonNull<Align2>>::dangling().as_ptr();
let four = <NonNull<Align4>>::dangling().as_ptr();

assert_eq!(four.mask(Alignment::of::<Align1>().mask()), four);
assert_eq!(four.mask(Alignment::of::<Align2>().mask()), four);
assert_eq!(four.mask(Alignment::of::<Align4>().mask()), four);
assert_ne!(one.mask(Alignment::of::<Align4>().mask()), one);
